titleStmt.title: ¶ The Printer vnto the gentle Reedar.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: ¶ The Printer vnto the gentle Reedar.

monogr.title: The calender of Scripture : VVhearin the Hebru, Challdian, Arabian, Phenician, Syrian, Persian, Greek and Latin names, of nations, cuntreys, men, weemen, idols, cities, hils, riuers, [and] of oother places in the holly Byble mentioned, by order of letters ar set, and turned into oour English toong. 1575
monogr.author: Patten, William

keywords.term: Dictionaries, vocabularies, phrase books, instruction in foreign languages

div.head: ¶ The Printer vnto the gentle Reedar.
div.p:
AS Gods maiestie in his creation of mankynde, endued the same amoong many other his gratious bodyly gifts, with no one thing of more hy price & excellency, then with the tool of toong for speech & voys, whearby in sort of words one to be able so deeply to strike the conceiuyng of his mynde into the vnderstandyng and sens of anoother: euen so at fyrst for vse thearof, vouchsafed his goodnes (as Scripture sheawthGenesis. 2. vs) to bryng al the wyghts he had made of the earth, and al the fouls of the ayr, vntoo oour fyrst father, to see and gyue them name: that what euer name he gaue them, wear they thearby called. Adam (sayth the text) by seuerall name called al lyuyng creatures, and euery foule of the ayr, and all beasts of the earth. Each of them (be we sure) by so apt and feet a tearm, touchyng eyther the qualitie, propertie, shape, coolour, condition, voys, or sum other such peculiar propriety of the creature named, as whoo so euer could attayn but to sum part of the knowledge of those causes, myght iustly acknowledge a singuler wisdom in the fyrst Namer, and an incomparable mercy in the gyuer of that wisdoom. Accordyng vnto which rule this fyrst Namer hym selfe, foormed out of ruddy clay, and thearby endued with the purest of complexions (as we tearm them) Rubicund or Sanguine, had hym selfe first to name in the Hebru (the fyrst of langages) Adam. As his make beyng the onelyAdam. Rubeus. wooman at her creation, counted moother and lyfe to all posteritie, and (for her breakyng the commaundment) the causer also of calamitie and wo, Adam named Eua. TheirEua mater omnium viuētium. Gene. 3. c. first sun, for the lands he shoold possess, for the moornyng he shoold cause, and for the enuie he shoold bear to his broother Abel, Adam named Cain. Their second sun, forCain. Possessio, Inuidia. the sorow that his death shoold rayse vp to them, he named Abel. After this sort was the leader of the Israelites out ofAbel. Luctus. Egypt, for that he was saued out of the water, called in the
Egyptian toong Moyses. His broother for his constancieMoyses. Sumptus •… xaqua. and strength in stablishment of the law amoong them, called a strong Mountayn, in Hebru Aaron. The moother ofAaron. Mon •…
•… ortis. oour raunsomer Christ, for the prerogatiue which by that byrth abooue all oother, she shoold be blessed withall, wasMa •… ia. Exaltata. named Exalted, in Hebru Maria. Her sun our Redeemer vouchsafed to haue name in remembrauns of his mercy Iesus, that is, health or Saluation. His foregoer, for that heI E S V S. Salus, •… aluator. shoold be Christes messenger, and for the speciall grace whear with he shoold excell, was called Ioannes, which is
•… oannes, domini g •… atia. an Angel, a messenger, or the grace of God. And after this rate may it wel be vnto vs a matter not onely not incredible, but also vndoutable, that all proper names of all things in al nations, wear vpon like foundation grounded at fyrst. So haue we & heer we of Names amoong vs, sum as I •… inde, out of the Greek, as Agnes, that signifieth a virgin, or chast: Agatha, Good: Andreas, Manly: Alexander, a Succorman: Actaeon, a Coastman: sum out of ye Latin, as Adeodatus, gyuen of God: Albion, oour Cuntrey, so called of the whyte Cleeues: Agrippa, of a hard byrth: sum out of oour auncient brittish, as Apprice, the sun of Rese: Aburgeuenny, (short Aburgenny,) the moouth of the ryuer Geuenny in Wales: Armoric, vpon the sea, the hither coast of Frauns and Flaunders. So haue we out of oour antike Saxony (whearvpon our English grewe) this name Adelmton (which amiss we call Edmonton) that soundeth in oour English now, the noble town, or town of noble men: Adelred, (short Aldred) noble counsel: Alboro, olld Town: Audley, or rather Adeley, The Princes, or the noble Iland. But as all thing ar found toly so in daunger of obliuions dayly ouertreadyng, or at least so to be subiect vnto corruption or chaunge to the woors, (the very footpath to forgetfulness) that hard it is to hold the remembrauns of beginnings (though of matters newe) and more hard a great deel to fetch out the originall of olld, so yet to bring proper Names to the reason and cause of theyr fyrst callyng, and so to keep them in memory, diuers learned men at sundry tymes and places (I vnderstand) haue sundryly well occupyed
them selues. Whearof too in especial for the Names in the holy Byble, one called Frauncis Ximenes, sumtyme an Archbishop of Tolede in Spayn, the oother of oour days now, Iohn Arquery a Bourdeauser. Out of both these (the one made to supply that the oother wāted) hath thear been compounded a perfit Calender according to the title of the book: whearin is syrst set the name, then the toong whearof it is: then the name expounded into Latin by the one or the oother, as best serues: and after put into our English for oour Cuntrey, which was the cheef cause of the trauayl taken: Lastly is thear added to the woord a note, both of the person or thyng what it was, and also of the book and chapter whear the same is mentioned. So the commoditie of this Calender consydering with my self, how pleasaunt for varietee, and profitable for knowledge it mought be vnto all: and thearwith how aptly it mought square with the trauayle I haue in hand in the reprintyng of oour English Byble: I could not stay me, but to vse the diligens and cunning I could, to get the copy soon into my hand. Which as with good curtesy it was deliuered me, so thought I it my part agayn, redyly fyrst in this small volume to impart it vnto you. If ought ye fynde in it more profitable then is in the Title vaunted: deem ye as I doo, to take that in good part, and the residue to the best: for as a ge •… le ear hartens a good toong, so dooth a curteous construction make a wyllyng wryter.

closer.salute: Fare ye hartely well in Christ,

dateline.date: this. ix. of Aprill. 1575. Anno regni Reginae nostrae feliciss. xvij.
